Sum of two sines and sum of two cosines

Here we obtain results that are widely used in areas of science and engineering such as vibration theory, wave theory and electric circuit theory.

We return to the identities angle addition formulae:

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(A+B ) &\equiv \sin A\cos B+\cos A\sin B\\ \sin (A-B) &\equiv \sin A\cos B-\cos A\sin B \end{aligned}\]

Adding these identities gives

\[\sin(A+B)+\sin(A-B)\equiv 2\sin A\cos B.\]

Subtracting the identities produces

\[\sin (A+B)-\sin(A-B)\equiv 2\cos A\sin B\]

It is now convenient to let \(C=A+B\) and \(D=A-B\) so that

\[A=\dfrac{C+D}{2} \qquad \text{and} \qquad B=\dfrac{C-D}{2}\]

The above then becomes:

\[\sin C+\sin D\equiv 2\sin\left(\dfrac{C+D}{2}\right)\cos \left(\dfrac{C-D}{2}\right) \]

Similarly:

\[\sin C-\sin D\equiv 2\cos\left(\dfrac{C+D}{2}\right)\sin \left(\dfrac{C-D}{2}\right) \]
